data.text:
@jojeedubs @OxfordVacGroup There is actually some work on this, including this paper that came out this week, looking specifically at Omicron. In short, if you get COVID even though you're vaccinated, it's likely to be asymptomatic/mild (same as in non-pregnant).

https://t.co/t5CMkzFO5t

@VikiLovesFACS @OxfordVacGroup I wish the infographic would share the impact of the vaccine on COVID outcomes in pregnancy, as so many vaxxed pregnant people can still get COVID and would be great to know how those stats are different if vaxxed

@DrPentland @OxfordVacGroup Ooh. And just found this - which I haven't read yet but also looks very relevant to this question...

https://t.co/W2TDnXaTis

@DrPentland @OxfordVacGroup Some indication it works though - in Scotland all perinatal deaths following COVID infection in pregnancy were in unvaccinated mothers. Back of an envelope calculation... with the rates at the time, the chance of that happening if vaccination didn't help is 0.01%.

2/

@DrPentland @OxfordVacGroup We have good data on vaccine effectiveness against severe disease in pregnancy, which I'll link below. What we still need is a firm estimate of effectiveness against preterm birth, stillbirth... 1/
@VikiLovesFACS @OxfordVacGroup Curious about the same data with vaccinated people?
@MichaelYeadon3 @VikiLovesFACS @OxfordVacGroup I think you are right, but I did have to think about it. I expect that the bottom section is better for vaccinated people but it doesn't say so here?
@doctor_regtools @VikiLovesFACS @OxfordVacGroup AIUI the top section is what happens to the person who is pregnant, the lower section is what happens to their pregnancy.
